senses.ex: She gave me a list of items to buy from the grocery store.

Tips.title: Physical Objects
Tips.description: Refers to physical items you can touch, often found in lists for shopping or tasks.
Tips.example: Please add another item to the package.

Tips.title: Not People
Tips.description: 'Item' shouldn't be used to refer to people, except in specific idiomatic expressions.
Tips.example: The wedding registry includes many kitchen items.

senses.de: A single piece of news or information
senses.ex: The next item on the news is about the new tax law.

Tips.title: News Context
Tips.description: In journalism, 'item' often relates to short pieces of news or articles.
Tips.example: Did you read the item about the election?

Tips.title: Not Opinions
Tips.description: News items should be factual reports, not opinion pieces or editorials.
Tips.example: The bulletin will cover several items on local updates.

senses.de: A single point on an agenda or list
senses.ex: Moving on to the next item on our meeting agenda...

Tips.title: Meeting Agendas
Tips.description: In meetings, 'item' usually refers to specific points discussed, often listed in order.
Tips.example: Let's address each agenda item one by one.

Tips.title: Not Casual Speech
Tips.description: Using 'item' in a professional context implies formality and structured discussion.
Tips.example: We have three new items of business today.

senses.ex: This item is the best seller in our store.

Tips.title: Commercial Goods
Tips.description: Refers to products or merchandise in a store or offered for sale online.
Tips.example: That clearance item is almost sold out.

Tips.title: Item Availability
Tips.description: Expresses whether something is in stock or part of the current sales offering.
Tips.example: Is this item still available for purchase?

senses.de: A person with whom one is having a romantic relationship
senses.ex: The two actors are an item now.

Tips.title: Romantic Pair
Tips.description: Colloquially, 'item' can describe two people in a romantic relationship.
Tips.example: I didn't realize they became an item last summer.

Tips.title: Informal Term
Tips.description: Use 'an item' to talk about couples in a light, informal way, not in formal writing.
Tips.example: Everyone knows they're an item; they're always together.

Article.wordDefinition:
An article is a written piece that provides information about a particular topic or subject.

It can be found in a newspaper, magazine, or online. Articles are usually longer than an item and are written by journalists or experts in a particular field.

An article is a written piece of information about a specific topic, while an item refers to a physical or non-physical object.

Component.wordDefinition:
Component refers to a part or element that is essential to a larger whole. It is commonly used in the context of technology and engineering, such as the components of a computer or a car engine.

Component refers to a part of a larger system, while item refers to an individual object or thing.

Element.wordDefinition:
Element refers to a fundamental part or component of something.

For example, in chemistry, oxygen is an element. In programming or computer science, an element could refer to a basic building block of software or code.

Element is applicable in scientific or technical contexts where fundamental components need to be identified or analyzed.

Entity.wordDefinition:
An entity is a thing or a being, whether it is abstract or concrete. It refers to something that exists in its own right and can be identified as a unique individual.

For example, a person, a company, or a country can all be entities. If I am talking about an object with a specific identity, I would use the word "entity.".

So, in general, when you want to refer to a specific individual or single thing, you would use the word entity, and when you want to refer to a specific object or thing among many, you would use the word "item."

Object.wordDefinition:
The words item and object can be similar in meaning, but they are used in different contexts.

Object is a more general term that refers to a tangible thing with physical properties. It could be something like a chair, book or car.

Objects can be touched, felt, and possessed. They are usually considered as individual entities that exist on their own.

So to simplify, item is a specific thing in a group or list, while object is a general term used to describe a physical thing that can be seen and touched.

Piece.wordDefinition:
Piece generally refers to a single unit that may make up a larger whole. For instance, a puzzle might be made up of several different pieces that fit together to create the completed picture.

Similarly, a cake can be divided into several pieces to be shared among a group of people.

Item is a more general term for any individual thing, while piece usually pertains to a single component of a larger thing.

Thing.wordDefinition:
Item refers to a specific thing that has a name or a label. For example, a pencil, a phone, or a book. It usually implies that the thing is important or has value.

Thing is a more general term that can refer to any object, idea, or phenomenon. It is less specific than item and doesn't necessarily have a name or a label.

Item is a more specific and formal term that refers to things with names, while thing is a more general and informal term that refers to anything.

Unit.wordDefinition:
Item refers to a specific thing, while the word unit refers to a quantity or measurement.

If you're measuring how much of something you have, you might use the word unit. For example, if you have a recipe that calls for two cups of flour, 'cup' is the unit of measurement.

So in general, item is more commonly used when referring to individual objects or things, while unit is more often used when referring to a specific quantity or measurement.

quotes.Text: Bring your kids along next time you go to the grocery store and ask them to help find the price per unit for the general grocery items. By comparing brands and looking for the best prices, kids will get in the habit of looking for deals and understand the value of the dollar.
